item.title: [ASM] Instruction Searcher
item.dc:creator: @qauters qauters
item.description:
@qauters wrote:

frank_:

i use asm because it is maintained, he probably fanboys it and will move on when something “cooler” comes along

The reason I moved to ASM is, that BCEL was unable to work on the HD client, therefor it’s useless for me.
ASM has no problems on it, therefor it’s better (cause a bytecode editing library should work on any kind of code)

Read full topic

item.title: [ASM] Instruction Searcher
item.dc:creator: @henry henry
item.description:
@henry wrote:

I’m curious as to why ASM is better than BCEL? And Fasga made (started) an ASM updater a while back, its on my hard drive somewhere… The updater structure would remain similar, I assume? So what exactly makes it more efficient?

Read full topic

item.title: [ASM] Instruction Searcher
item.dc:creator: @qauters qauters
item.description:
@qauters wrote:

Well, since there is hardly any info on ASM updaters around while it’s so much better then using BCEL, I decided to release my instruction searcher.
This makes the switch from BCEL (instruction list driven) to ASM (visitor driven) a lot easier.
Obviously there are cases you should use the visitor based way, because of performs reasons.
But this doesn’t work on every occasion, so an instruction searcher is vital for a successful ASM updater.

First how do you use it:
Well just like this:

		for(ClassReader cr : classes)
		{
			ClassNode cn = new ClassNode();
			cr.accept(cn, 0);
			
			//Sadly they didn't parameterized their arraylists
			for(Iterator it = cn.methods.iterator(); it.hasNext(); )
			{
				QIS s = new QIS((MethodNode) it.next());
				if(!s.hasInstructions()) continue;
				//Do what ever you want, like s.next() etc
			}
		}

Since you are only allowed to have a maximum of 20000 characters in a post, the instruction searcher has been added as an attachment.

Read full topic
